title: Is it genetically possible for a human to be 'perfect'? - Quora

response.answer_text: The problem is that genetics doesn’t work that way. It’s all trade-offs and balancing acts. There’s no “perfect”, merely a whole lot of “good enoughs”. For example: you might think that having a super-high intelligence would be something to include in your “perfect human”. So why haven’t we evolved it already? Probably because if the intelligence gets *too* high, you start hitting all sorts of cognitive hazards. Memorable Movie Death #3: Vizzini From Princess Bride That’s what happens when you’re too smart - you can overthink yourself to death. Another example: humans are not the fastest animal on land when measured over short distances. Not even close. Evolving to walk upright and make hands more usable meant that we could never hope to match speeds with a four-legged animal. However… walking upright and having a good brain means you can invent and carry a spear. And that’s a game changer. There’s a lot of carnivores that can outrun a human - but most of them have enough sense to leave a human with weapons alone. And walking upright is a game changer in another way. Our hip design guarantees we can’t out-sprint animals. But it’s damned efficient. We can run marathons. Ultra-marathons of 50 and 100 miles. And that’s a game changer too. See that gazelle? It’s going to be lunch. It may take a while, but it’s going to happen. Pick up your spear, and run towards the gazelle. It, of course, runs off. Keep running. You get close again, and it runs off again, but not as fast. Do this 20 or 30 times, and you may not even need the spear - the gazelle may literally drop dead of exhaustion. And having found that niche of being able to run further than anything else on the plains of Africa, we acquired a bunch of other features. We lost almost all our body hair, making it easier to stay cool while chasing that antelope for 3–4 hours in the Serengeti heat. That’s going to come back and bite us in the butt in a few hundred thousand years when our descendants try to live in Europe, but by then they’ll have learned how to skin animals that *do* have fur and make clothing. Ever wonder why getting even a minor cut on the head bleeds so much? It’s because the blood vessels in our head take a weird path. To keep our brain cool while running in the heat, the blood vessels go up and around the *outside* of the skull where the blood can cool off before going to the brain. Yeah, it means you can lose a lot of blood from a minor wound - but back on the plains of Africa, getting that sort of wound probably meant that you’d encountered a carnivore that wasn’t afraid of a primate with a spear. If that happens, that scalp wound is the least of your problems.. And it’s the same sort of thing all the way down. Trade-offs all over the place, over even the most basic things. Be warm-blooded? You can live in cold places - but your food requirements just went up by a factor of 10 or more. An alligator can live for over a year off one good meal, we don’t have that option.

It must surely be possible. But it seems like if someone is really good in sports, they may be lacking in some other area. I have met men who were really good at sports AND really smart but they died early. I have met people who were mentally challenged but very happy and very strong. I have always wanted to be taller but my taller friends and brothers had back problems and foot problems. I had an uncle that was 6–5″ and very smart (Chemist) and made 3 million in the stock market. He was a very nice guy and lived to be 95 years old, But he would not let my aunt correct the children which ruined their marriage and made home life very difficult. I believe in abortion but we never know what could have happened. George Washington Carver was the product of a rape. Perfect how exactly? Super muscular Mr Universe, won’t be a good cave explorer, he won’t fit all the tight turns and tunnels. Man with the biggest brain, most powerful body, needs a lot of calories to live and would probably die during a mass starvation. Fat guy, last man standing during a mass starvation, is unattractive when there is food everywhere. Blue eyes, fair white skin… Aryan master race of the Nazis, gets cataract, goes blind, and gets skin damage with skin cancer if he lives near the tropics like in Australia or South Africa. Perfection is relative and situation specific.

Many “recessive” genes produce negative health consequences but, because they are recessive, a large fraction of them “hide” in heterozygous individuals. In other words, the presence of a form (allele) that’s “good” produces whatever effect is necessary for a decent level of health. (Example: albinism in Tanzania, where albino babies are killed — yet 2/3 of the albino’s siblings carry genes causing albinism, which guarantees perpetuation of the genes.) “Modifying” genes makes good science fiction, but we can’t do that yet, and we don’t even know what would lead to choosing the perfect form (if there is one) among the possibilities, e.g., among ABO blood groups, would one choose to have the A or B form or the “neither” option, which would code for O?

No, because the concept of “perfection” is a human value judgment, which has no objective meaning. If this sounds strange to you, try answering this question: Is a komodo dragon more or less perfect than a strawberry plant? Is a pufferfish more or less perfect than a tapeworm? The questions are meaningless, as is the concept of “perfection”, except possibly as applied to things which humans make — and in those cases, “perfect” is whatever humans decide it is. But not to humans themselves.

That isn’t necessary. I am already perfect. You do know, I hope, that “perfection” is completely undefined, and means whatever each of us wants it to mean. But, it is certainly true that it is within human capability to genetically modify a human before he (we all know the perfect human will be a man) is born. At some time in the future it will almost certainly be possible to tailor an unborn human in just about any way desired. The unexpected consequences are also certain to pop up at that time. Genes work in teams, and there are huge numbers of teams that can work together.

No, because there are so many different definitions of “perfect”. Do you want a brilliant athlete, a healthy and long-lived scholar, a hard-working and genetically engineered worker, someone modified to live in space for decades without hurting their health?

Pretty much what everyone else said… plus… I can’t help comparing this to people that get plastic surgery… it seems like perfection is somewhat subjective and also a slippery slope… leading sometimes to less that “perfect” results.
Darwinian selection is about passing on traits that improve survive-ability. Seems a pretty perfect solution to an ever changing physical domain.
Mathematical theorems can be proven perfect. Nothing in the real world is perfect.
